story:
In June 2021 we are walking 100km to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support. The challenge will take place in the beautiful Lake District. We will walk through the night, to complete the challenge in one go. 

Macmillan Cancer Support is an incredible charity that has recently been supporting someone very important to us. To say thank you, we would like to try to raise as much as possible. We would greatly appreciate any donations, little or large, to help us reach our fundraising goal.

In June 2019 we completed the Jurassic Coast 100km challenge in 26.5 hours. It was a physically and mentally tough challenge, where we had to overcome many obstacles from swollen knees to the literal obstacles of hopping over what felt like hundreds of farm stiles. Rather than looking back on how challenging the walk was, we both look back on the experience and think that we can do better. This time our aim is to complete the challenge in under 26.5 hours. story:
Since 2010, M&S and Macmillan have been working together to help make a huge difference for people living with cancer in local communities across the UK.

The enthusiasm, support and hard work of M&S employees and customers has raised an incredible £19.4 million for Macmillan to date. In 2019 alone, the fantastic £2.1 million raised by M&S was enough to fund around 37 Macmillan professionals for one year, from nurses and occupational therapists to psychologists and doctors to provide vital support for people living with cancer.

With Coronavirus having had a huge impact on fundraising events, your support has never been more important, as we safeguard against cancer becoming the forgotten C. With social distancing measures in place, this year, were challenging M&S colleagues to get creative with their fundraising and activities, using virtual challenges and digital channels to make the most of their efforts this year!

Thank you so much for your invaluable support.

story:
Before COVID-19 hit, many of Macmillan’s funds were raised through social events like coffee mornings... obviously with the current climate these events haven’t been able to happen.  Since seeing the drastic effect this has had on their funds I decided that I wanted to help in anyway I can.  £100 isn’t a huge amount of money but it would make a difference.  

Many individuals and family’s rely on the support from Macmillan and their nurses.  Their work is really incredible. 

So starting from Monday the 12th of October I am taking part in their Forty Days of Fitness Challenge and anyone who knows me will know this is a challenge! My goal is to spend at least 30 mins every day doing some form of exercise whether it’s being at the gym, going for a walk or going for a run! I would be very grateful for any donations in support of this challenge and the wonderful work that this charity do. 


Thank you,

Jade

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge weve faced in our 60 year history. And its led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, weve never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into groundbreaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the worlds biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we cant drop the ball now.

The reason I have chosen this charity is because my Grandad sadly passed away in March this year, he had multiple strokes and it was devastating for us all. story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. 

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss. 

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society. 

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

So why Marie Curie? 

I do hope you'll take a little time to study the attached fact sheet and begin to appreciate how invaluable even the smallest donation will be to the Marie Curie nurses and carers who wear the familiar 'daffodil badge' and provide such wonderful support for those who may be very seriously ill. I have been happy to raise small amounts, when so unassumingly invited to do so, each spring ... yes, at the time of the daffodils ... over the past ten years; along with many others, I know. With all the challenges of 2020, Marie Curie needs and deserve any support we can provide. Who knows which one of our relations, friends or even one of us might not benefit from Marie Curie care at some time in the future. 

Marie Curie Nurses work on the front line, night and day, in people’s
homes across the UK, providing hands-on care and vital emotional  support. If you’re living with a terminal illness, our nurses will help you to feel safe, supported and cared-for in the place where you’re most comfortable

£20 pays for an hour of expert care and emotional support for someone living with a terminal illness, in the comfort of their own home.

£29 pays the running costs of your local care co-ordination centre for an hour, so that as many people as possible have access to the care they need, when they need it.

£41 kits out a Marie Curie Nurse, so they’re ready to face anything with a smile and the sense of pride that their uniform brings.

£400 pays the running costs of your local care co-ordination centre for a day, so that Marie Curie Nurses can provide hands-on care in the homes of the people that need it.

£500 pays to train a nurse or healthcare assistant for a year, so they have the knowledge and expertise to give quality care to those who need it.

So what's in it for me?

Having done regular 2 mile 'power walks' over the past two and a half years, and completed 250 walks over a total distance of 500 miles by the end of 2019, I have done a further 160 walks (320 miles) so far in 2020. Covid 19 'Lockdown' from 23rd March was a great incentive to get out 3 or 4 times a week, especially when taking outside exercise on one's own was deemed to be acceptable by Boris & Co and with the spring and summer weather being so good. Doing a 4 mile walk in under 1 hour, back in May,  helped me raise £100 for the Elizabeth House Adult Day Centre in Cookham with the sponsorship of Barn Close residents, and gave me the urge to take on even bigger challenges. Reading about the forthcoming annual Maidenhead Boundary Walk in the local paper, a few weeks ago, was just the incentive I needed. As usual, the Walk is organised by Maidenhead Rotary, but has been modified so as to be Covid friendly. As a result, at 13 miles, the Walk is slightly shorter and can be undertaken on any day of my choice between 4th and 25th October. Yes, I can, hopefully, avoid any of the crowded family days and any bad weather, but I shall still be required to prove that I have done the Walk before I can start pestering those who have agreed to sponsor me! (There will be photographic evidence on this page). All in all, the cause is a good one, the course is delightfully scenic (Penny and I completed the last of four walks to recce the circuit earlier today) and, above all, I'm up for it. All being well, next Thursday 15th October (anniversary of my father's passing) will be the big day. Wish me luck and sponsor me generously if you possibly can. I shall keep you updated.

Regards

John Q

story:
Our beautiful Rainbow Rachel passed away peacefully at home on 2nd October, 10 months after her brain tumour diagnosis. Rachel was just 25 years old. Rachel was diagnosed with an incredibly rare brainstem tumour and showed so much strength, bravery and determination throughout her illness. Sadly, despite this, this was a fight that Rachel just could not win no matter how hard she tried.

Rachel was an incredibly popular individual who was loved by so many people. She will be missed immensely by her parents David and Gill, fiancé Adam, sister Jade, Nanna Florence and all of her friends and extended family. Our lives will never be the same without her. Rachel could not wait to marry her fiancé Adam, meticulously planning every detail of their big day. It breaks our hearts that due to the progression of Rachel’s illness her dream wedding was never able to go ahead. 

Rachel will be remembered as someone who was incredibly caring, generous, selfless and loyal, making her an amazing friend to so many. Her sense of humour and infectious laugh will be remembered by all who knew her. Rachel had several passions including music, singing, hosting social events for friends, quizzes, fitness and travel. Rachel was vibrant, intelligent and had achieved so much in her life. She was awarded a First Class Honours Degree in Linguistics at Lancaster University and subsequently obtained a place on the prestigious Ambitious Futures graduate scheme. Rachel went on to work at Lancaster University in the Communications Department. Rachel loved her work and was a much valued asset to her team and colleagues. We are all so proud of her.  

We have so many amazing memories of Rachel and take some comfort in knowing that she is no longer suffering and is at peace. Rachel was an inspiration to so many people and we will always remember her as a ray of sunshine who  loved rainbows, unicorns and life itself. 

Rachel’s funeral will take place on Thursday 15th October at 12.30pm at East Lancashire Crematorium (Radcliffe). We are asking everyone to wear bright colours (no black) as per Rachel’s wishes. Unfortunately due to current Covidrestrictions we are very limited as to those who will be able to join us inside the service. 

In Rachel’s memory we are asking for donations to Marie Curie, a charity that has offered invaluable support to Rachel and our family during this incredibly difficult time.

Thank you for taking the time to read Rachel’s story. 

With love,

Gill, Dave, Jade and Adam

eventName: Iceland Trek 2021 for West Midlands Hospice
story:
I have signed up to do a trek of Iceland in memory of my Dad who passed away in the Marie Curie west midlands hospice in July 2019.

Here is the link to what the trek actually consists of, and a little bit about what the hospice does to help people who are ill and their families.

https://www.mariecurie.org.uk/get-involved/charity-events/overseas-challenges/iceland-west-midlands

Our Solihull Hospice has been caring for local people since 1965.Its a warm and welcoming place where we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones, every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 200 volunteers who play a vital role in the running of the hospice. We have a 24-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish. Our out-patient unit offers clinics, therapies and group sessions and freshly cooked lunches made by our chefs. We also support carers and families, including children, with practical advice, counselling and bereavement support groups. We need to raise £9,600 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Solihull get the care and support they need.

charity.name: WaterAid
charity.registrationNumber: 288701 (England and Wales) and SC039479 (Scotland)
story:
On 6 October 2020, large areas of East London were without running water for a few hours because of a burst pipe. At first I was fed up, then, talking to my kids, I realised what a privilege it is to expect hot and cold running water 24/7. I carried one bucket of water in from my garden to flush our toilets, and wondered what it would be like to have to walk miles carrying water every day. I asked my kids to use hand sanitiser before eating, and wondered what it would be like to worry constantly about them getting ill from dirty water, or not having enough water to keep clean. 

Here's what WaterAid say:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

So rather than just thinking about it, I decided to do something, and this felt like a small thing I could do that others might want to do too.
